fields.Title of Contribution: Development and Initial Validation of a Measure to Assess Accessibility and Inclusion Factors Related to Tier 1 in Schoolwide Positive Behavioral Interventions and Supports
fields.Publisher: ProQuest Central; ProQuest Dissertations & Theses Global
fields.Description/Abstract: Background: Schoolwide positive behavioral interventions and supports (PBIS) is<br>an evidence-based framework for implementing a continuum of behavior support<br>practices in schools to improve student outcomes. Research suggests that students with<br>extensive support needs (ESN) may not have access to the complete continuum of<br>behavioral supports within their schools or be included in the implementation of PBIS.<br>Research also suggests that some special education teachers and other educators who<br>work with students with ESN may be uninformed about PBIS initiatives or excluded<br>from implementation and evaluation processes in their schools. Investigators have<br>examined PBIS evaluation tools and found the measures contained exceptions to<br>providing support and instruction to all students and staff, such that students with ESN<br>and educators associated with these learners could be omitted when the tools were<br>administered to evaluate implementation fidelity. Purpose: The purpose of this study was<br>to develop and initially validate a new add-on scale for the Tiered Fidelity Inventory<br>(TFI; version 3.0). The new add-on scale, titled the Tiered Fidelity Inventory-<br>Accessibility & Inclusion Rating (TFI-AIR), was designed to measure the extent to which<br>implementation of Tier 1 in PBIS is accessible for and inclusive of students with ESN.<br>Method: This study was conducted in two phases. In Phase 1 we assessed the content<br>validity of the TFI-AIR. In Phase 2 we pretested the TFI-AIR in schools and assessed the<br>4<br>measure’s usability according to Tier 1 team members. Results: Results from Phase 1<br>indicated that the content of the TFI-AIR was valid for assessing fidelity related to<br>students with ESN. Results from Phase 2 showed that all Tier 1 team members rated the<br>TFI-AIR as an efficient and effective measure that teams should administer at least once<br>or annually as part of their regular practice. Conclusion: Although future research is<br>needed before disseminating the TFI-AIR, this study provides initial evidence that the<br>content of the TFI-AIR is valid for assessing accessibility and inclusion factors related to<br>Tier 1 implementation for students with ESN, and there may be demand for such a<br>measure from implementation teams interested in developing their PBIS systems to be<br>more equitable and inclusive for students who have been historically marginalized or<br>underserved in schools.
